content:
Just finished reading Atomic Habits by James Clear, and honestly, it’s one of those books that makes you want to immediately reorganize your entire life. Rating it a solid 9/10.
The Core Concept The book revolves around the compounding effect - small changes that seem insignificant at first but compound into remarkable results over time. Clear argues that you don’t need massive changes; you need consistent, tiny improvements.
Key Takeaways That Hit Different Environment is Everything Your environment plays a critical role in defining habit behaviors. The most significant contributor? Your visual environment. Want to break a bad habit? Break your exposure to the cue that triggers it in the first place.
I’ve been testing this with my phone usage at night - instead of relying on willpower, I just leave it downstairs. As Clear says: “The secret to self-control is designing a reality where you don’t need it.”
The Two-Minute Rule Good habits shouldn’t feel like a challenge to perform. The whole task might be difficult, but the first two minutes should be easy. This has been a game-changer for my workout routine.
Join the Right Culture One of the best strategies to build better habits is to join a culture where your desired behavior is the normal behavior. This makes so much sense when you think about it.
My Personal Experiment I’m committing to doing something physical every single day for a month. Right now, 30 pushups is challenging for me, so we’ll see where I am at the end of 30 days. Tracking progress seems to be crucial according to Clear.
The Boredom Problem Clear warns that when you get good at something and it becomes a habit, expect to get bored. When boredom hits, you might lose incentive to maintain the habit. The solution? Stay deliberate in your approach and keep assessing your performance.
Bottom Line This isn’t just another self-help book. It’s a practical guide backed by research that actually gives you actionable strategies. If you’re looking to build better systems in your life, this is worth the read.
The compounding effect is real, and small changes really do add up to big results over time.

content:
Finally got around to reading Dune by Frank Herbert after Harrison kept recommending it. My honest take? It’s… complicated.
The Good The first book is genuinely good. Herbert created this incredibly detailed universe with complex politics, ecology, and mysticism all woven together. The world-building is impressive, and you can see why it’s considered a sci-fi classic.
The movie (at least the first one) was visually stunning and did justice to the source material. Denis Villeneuve really understood the assignment.
The Not-So-Good Here’s where I might get some hate: the rest of the series? Meh.
I know, I know - people love the entire saga, but after the first book, it felt like Herbert was trying too hard to expand on something that worked perfectly as a standalone story. The pacing gets weird, and some of the philosophical tangents feel forced.
Rating: 7.1/10 Yeah, that’s oddly specific, but that’s where it lands for me. It’s good, but maybe not the life-changing masterpiece everyone made it out to be.
Why It Still Matters Despite my lukewarm feelings about the series as a whole, I get why Dune is important. It influenced basically every piece of space opera that came after it. The ecological themes, the political intrigue, the chosen one narrative - it’s all here first.
Plus, in our current climate crisis, Herbert’s focus on ecology and resource scarcity feels more relevant than ever.
Should You Read It? If you’re into sci-fi at all, yes. Read the first book. It’s a classic for a reason, and you’ll understand so many references in other works once you do.
Just don’t feel obligated to read the entire series if the first one doesn’t completely blow you away. Sometimes one great book is enough.
What did you think of Dune? Am I completely wrong about the sequels? Let me know - I’m always down to discuss sci-fi takes.

content:
The Three-Body Problem by Cixin Liu is the kind of sci-fi that makes you question everything about humanity’s place in the universe. Rating: 8.1/10 (yeah, a lot of my sci-fi reads end up around there).
What Makes It Special This isn’t your typical Western sci-fi. Liu brings a distinctly Chinese perspective to concepts like fate vs. free will, and it’s refreshing. The book feels less about individual heroism and more about humanity as a whole facing an existential threat.
The Big Ideas That Stuck With Me The Dark Forest Theory Without spoiling too much, the deterrence theory that Luo Ji develops is genuinely chilling. It’s this idea that the universe is like a dark forest where every civilization is a hunter, and making noise (revealing your location) is basically suicide.
Technology That Feels Alien The sophons - these subatomic particles that can unfold into higher dimensions - are some of the most creative alien tech I’ve encountered. It’s not just “humans but with better guns.” It’s genuinely alien thinking.
The Folding of Dimensions The way Liu describes the breakdown of dimensions through the painting metaphor is beautiful and terrifying. The idea that our 3D reality could be flattened into 2D is the kind of concept that keeps you up at night.
The Fairy Tale That Explains Everything The most memorable part is this fairy tale in the final book about a kingdom with no stories, two princes, a princess, and a painter who can trap people in paintings. It sounds weird, but it’s actually a brilliant way to explain incredibly advanced technology through metaphor.
The umbrella that protects you from being “painted,” the soap bubbles that let you travel at light speed - it’s all there, wrapped in this deceptively simple story.
Human Nature Under Pressure What I found fascinating is how Liu explores human selfishness through the Wallfacer/Wallbreaker project. When faced with extinction, do we come together or tear each other apart? The answer is… complicated.
The choice between love and mutual destruction (especially with the female MC who lacks the conviction to escalate conflicts) felt very real and human.
Why It Works This trilogy doesn’t give you easy answers or clear good guys vs. bad guys. Everyone’s just trying to survive, and survival makes people do terrible things. It’s less about heroism and more about the mathematics of extinction.
The time scales involved - we’re talking about the heat death of the universe here - put human concerns in perspective in a way that’s both humbling and terrifying.
Bottom Line If you like your sci-fi hard, your concepts big, and your philosophy Eastern, this is for you. It’s not an easy read, but it’s rewarding. Just be prepared to have your assumptions about first contact completely shattered.
The entire Remembrance of Earth’s Past series is worth the journey, even if it gets heavy at times. Sometimes the best sci-fi is the kind that makes you uncomfortable.

content:
The Sovereign Individual by James Dale Davidson and Lord William Rees-Mogg is one of those books that either feels like prophecy or pretentious rambling, depending on when you read it. Rating: 7.8/10.
The Central Thesis Written in 1997, the book predicts the rise of digital currencies, remote work, and the decline of nation-states. The authors argue that technology will eventually allow individuals to become “sovereign” - free from traditional government control and taxation.
What They Got Right Looking back from 2024, it’s honestly scary how much they nailed:
Digital currencies - They predicted Bitcoin before Bitcoin existed Remote work revolution - COVID just accelerated what they saw coming Decline of traditional employment - The gig economy explosion Tax avoidance through technology - Digital nomads and crypto are making this real What Feels Off The book has this libertarian fantasy vibe that assumes everyone can just opt out of society. It’s very much written from the perspective of wealthy individuals who have the luxury of choice.
The tone can be pretty elitist - there’s this underlying assumption that only the “cognitive elite” will benefit from these changes, while everyone else gets left behind.
The Crypto Connection This book is basically required reading in crypto circles, and I can see why. The idea of programmable money that exists outside government control is central to their vision of sovereignty.
But reading it now, after seeing how crypto has actually played out, some of their optimism feels naive. Turns out governments are pretty good at adapting and regulating new technologies.
Why It’s Still Relevant Even if you disagree with their conclusions, the book makes you think about the relationship between technology, power, and individual freedom. In an age of increasing surveillance and government overreach, these questions matter.
The COVID response showed us how quickly governments can restrict movement and commerce. Maybe the authors were onto something about the need for alternative systems.
Bottom Line It’s a thought-provoking read that’s aged better than most futurism books. Whether you buy into their vision or not, they were clearly thinking about trends that most people missed.
Worth reading if you’re interested in economics, technology, or just want to understand why some people are so passionate about decentralization.
Just take the more extreme predictions with a grain of salt. The future is usually messier and more complicated than anyone predicts.

The Central Thesis

Written in 1997, the book predicts the rise of digital currencies, remote work, and the decline of nation-states. The authors argue that technology will eventually allow individuals to become “sovereign” - free from traditional government control and taxation.
title: The Sovereign Individual: Prescient or Pretentious?
